Come on, baby, don’t be cold as ice

It might be of interest to note the similarity between this line and the one in Elvis' ‘Treat Me Nice’ which Lennon/McCartney were most likely familiar with: ‘If you don’t want me to be cold as ice / Treat me nice’

My baby said she’s traveling on the one after 909
 I said move over honey I’m traveling on that line

Paul McCartney later said that he was trying to imitate American railroad songs of the time, such as Rock Island Line. Thus, “909” is a reference to a freight-train line, and the girl he sings about got on the one “after it.”
